annotation.text: Drosophila Ninjurin A Induces Nonapoptotic Cell Death
Drosophila Ninjurin A Induces Nonapoptotic Cell Death
In ectopic expression studies, NijA induced cell death, as evidenced by cell loss and acridine orange staining.
These dying cells did not display hallmarks of apoptotic cells including TUNEL staining and inhibition by p35, indicating that NijA induced nonapoptotic cell death.
In cell culture, NijA also induced cell death, which appeared to be cell autonomous.
These in vivo studies identify a new role for the Ninjurin family in inducing nonapoptotic cell death.

Rather, in larvae the protein distribution is altered in immune tissues after injury, and NijA protein levels can be elevated via the Tl immune signaling pathway, suggesting that NijA may function in the immune system.

In a gain-of-function approach, however, we found that NijA induced cell death at a level comparable to the known apoptotic gene hid, yet the NijA-induced death does not have the hallmarks of apoptosis.
From cell culture studies, we conclude that NijA is likely to induce cell death in a cell-autonomous manner, rather than as a nonautonomous signaling molecule.
Ectopic expression of NijA induces nonapoptotic cell death
Hml expressing cells, visualized by Hml>GFP, can be observed under the cuticle of whole third instar larvae (Fig. 3A,B); however, when NijA is co-expressed, the cells appear to be absent (Fig. 3C).
The similarity of these results suggested that NijA induces cell death in differentiated blood cells.

Hml expressing cells, visualized by Hml>GFP, can be observed under the cuticle of whole third instar larvae (Fig. 3A,B); however, when NijA is co-expressed, the cells appear to be absent (Fig. 3C). To compare the effects of NijA to a known apoptosis inducer, we drove the expression of hid with hml-GAL4, and found a similar loss of GFP-labeled cells (Fig. 3D).

We examined dissected lymph glands expressing NijA. Although 7/7 control (hml>GFP) lymph glands did not stain with acridine orange, which can only permeate dead cells, in contrast all lymph glands expressing either NijA or the apoptosis inducer hid stained brightly with acridine orange (7 of each genotype, compare Fig. 3G-I'). The dying cells appeared to be restricted to differentiated cells that express hml, as undifferentiated hemocytes expressing hemese but not hml were still present in lymph glands expressing hml>NijA or hml>hid (Fig. 2J-L).
Thus NijA induces cell death when ectopically expressed.

By these criteria, we found that 10/11 hid-expressing lymph glands were apoptotic, whereas 22/23 GFP lymph glands were TUNEL-negative and 9/13 NijA-expressing lymph glands were TUNEL-negative (Fig. 3J''-L'').

By these criteria, we found that 10/11 hid-expressing lymph glands were apoptotic, whereas 22/23 GFP lymph glands were TUNEL-negative and 9/13 NijA-expressing lymph glands were TUNEL-negative (Fig. 3J''-L'').
Examining GFP-labeled hemocytes in live animals, we found that p35 inhibited Hid-induced cell death as expected, but importantly p35 did not inhibit NijA-induced cell death (Fig. 3M-P).
Examining GFP-labeled hemocytes in live animals, we found that p35 inhibited Hid-induced cell death as expected, but importantly p35 did not inhibit NijA-induced cell death (Fig. 3M-P).

When transfected with only the GFP plasmid, 39% of cells expressed GFP, and 8% of cells were dead as measured by trypan blue exclusion (Fig. 5A), consistent with the baseline rate of cell death we measured in these cultures (Fig. 4). In contrast, when cells were co-transfected with NijA and GFP, only 9% of cells expressed GFP, and 37% of the cultured cells were dead as measured by trypan blue exclusion (Fig. 5A).

We found that D140 was absolutely required, as this point mutation ablated NijA's ability to induce death; importantly the D140A mutant protein was not able to localize correctly to the cell surface (Fig. 5D-F), suggesting that cell-surface localization is critical for inducing death.

Surprisingly, two mutants seemed to increase the potency of NijA, as D124A or the double mutant K131A, K132A were more toxic to cells than wild-type NijA, resulting in no GFP-positive cells; yet because the fraction of dead cells was similar to the sum of the baseline death rate plus the transfection rate, it appears that this overactive toxic mutant still killed in a cell-autonomous manner.
Taken together, these data strongly suggest that NijA induces death in a cell-autonomous manner, requiring cell surface localization to kill cells.
We conclude that when expressed at high levels, NijA kills cells by a nonapoptotic mechanism, likely in a cell autonomous manner.
As in cell culture, the double mutant phenocopied wild-type NijA, whereas the ectodomain alone did not induce cell death comparable to wild-type NijA (Fig. 6).
These data indicate that NijA induces nonapoptotic cell death.
Our genetic gain-of-function studies indicate that NijA induces cell death in a cell-autonomous manner.
Our study highlights a novel and potentially medially important role for the conserved Ninjurin family in inducing cell death.
